India Tolak Masuk Grup Dagang se-Asia Pasifik, Ini Kata Wamenlu
05 Nov 2019, 11:34 by Trio Hamdani


Foto: Wamenlu Mahendra Siregar (Andhika Prasetia/detikcom)

Jakarta - Kementerian Luar Negeri (Kemlu) buka suara soal sikap India menolak bergabung dalam pakta blok perdagangan utama di Asia Pasifik. Sikap tersebut disampaikan oleh seorang diplomat India Vijay Thakur Singh pada Senin (4/11), di acara KTT ASEAN ke-35 di Thailand.Wakil Menteri Luar Negeri (Wamenlu) Mahendra Siregar mengatakan, masalah tersebut tidak perlu didramatisir."Tentu dalam teknis negosiasinya harus terus dilakukan. Idealnya memang 16 negara itu. Tapi kalau memang nanti ternyata perlu penjadwalan untuk yang lebih siap duluan barangkali saya rasa wajar saja, tidak usah terlalu didramatisasi," kata dia di Hotel Indonesia Kempinski, Jakarta Pusat, Selasa (5/11/2019).Perjanjian perdagangan tersebut seharusnya disepakati oleh 16 negara. Perjanjian dagang tersebut adalah Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP).Namun menurut dia, pernyataan Perdana Menteri (PM) India Narendra Modi sebenarnya cukup positif berkaitan dengan konteks perjanjian dagang RCEP."Saya dengar statement-nya PM Modi sebenarnya sangat positif dalam arti ingin supaya mendukung dan menjadi bagian dari penyelesaian RCEP yang segera. Jadi saya megangnya itu ya," lanjutnya.Mahendra mengatakan India tidak bisa seenaknya masuk ke dalam perjanjian tersebut nantinya."Tidak bisa kapan pun (masuk) tentu, tapi ada prosesnya dengan catatan tentu hal-hal yang sudah dinegosiasikan harus dipenuhi," tambahnya. India Refuses to Enter Asia-Pacific Trade Groups, This is the Word of the Foreign Minister
05 Nov 2019, 11:34 by Trio Hamdani


Photo: Deputy Minister Mahendra Siregar (Andhika Prasetia / detikcom)

Jakarta - The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Ministry of Foreign Affairs) openly voiced the attitude of India refusing to join the main trade bloc pact in the Asia Pacific. That attitude was conveyed by Indian diplomat Vijay Thakur Singh on Monday (4/11), at the 35th ASEAN Summit in Thailand. Deputy Foreign Minister (Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs) Mahendra Siregar said, the problem did not need to be dramatized. "Certainly in the technical negotiations "The ideal is indeed the 16 countries. But if indeed later it turns out that it needs scheduling for the more prepared first, maybe I think it's natural, not to be over-dramatized," he said at the Kempinski Indonesia Hotel, Central Jakarta, Tuesday (11/5 / 2019). The trade agreement should be agreed to by 16 countries. The trade agreement is the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP). But according to him, the statement of the Indian Prime Minister (PM) Narendra Modi is actually quite positive with regard to the context of the RCEP trade agreement. "I heard that PM Modi's statement was actually very positive in the sense of wanting support and be part of the immediate RCEP settlement. So I hold it, yes, "he continued. Mahendra said that India cannot enter into the agreement later on." It cannot at any time (enter) of course, but there is a process with notes of course the negotiated thing must be fulfilled, "he added.
